slts.slt: I have a Cardano Browser wallet extension installed on my computer.
I have NodeJS installed on my local computer.
I am familiar with some essentials of the React framework, like components, props, and hooks.
I can integrate Mesh into a new Project.
I can use Mesh to connect a CIP-30 compliant wallet to a decentralized application.
I can see information about my wallet in my web browser.
I can use Mesh React hooks.
I can use a Mesh Provider to get information about the blockchain.
I can use Mesh Resolvers to convert data so that it is useful in application.
I can design an application on Cardano by understanding what Mesh does and does not do.
I can build a simple, valid spending transaction using Mesh. (Or consider this: I can build a donate button.)
I can use Mesh to build advanced transactions that include native assets, metadata, or multiple outputs.
I can build invalid transactions that exceed protocol limitations, and I can explain when a transaction will be valid based on transaction context.
I can mint a new token using native scripts or plutus scripts.
I can build a valid multi-signature transaction.
I can lock funds in a smart contract validator address.
I can unlock funds from a smart contract validator address.
I can build an app component that allows users to stake to a specified stakepool.
I can build an app component that allows users to sign verified messages.
I can set up a Mesh App Wallet instance.
I can build a service that performs automatic transaction building, signing, and submission.
I can return a partially-signed transaction to frontend for collecting multiple signatures.

modules.title: Building Transactions with Mesh Lower Level APIs - MeshTxBuilder

slts.slt: I can send ADA to myself.
I can send value to a script with inline datum attached.
I can unlock funds from a validator.
I can mint a native asset using a Plutus minting validator.
I can unlock funds from a script while minting a smart contract native token at the same time.
I can build a transaction by providing an object specification.
I can get parameterized scripts for a transaction dynamically at the time of transaction building.
I can navigate the Mesh source code repository for debugging.
I can describe precisely what error I am facing with Mesh with ways to reproduce.
I can add on the existing issue / create a new issue on Github for potential bugs.
I can fork Mesh's repository and create a pull request for potential improvements or fixes.
